questions.question: Which of the following layers is not present in the cardiac valve?
You are conducting an autopsy of an elderly patient who was found dead in his home. Whichof the following changes in the heart will not be suggestive of normal aging?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, an increase in the size of the left ventricle is not normally seen in the heartof an elderly person. The size of the left ventricular cavity is decreased in the aged heart,particularly in the base-to-apex dimension. This change is exacerbated by systemic hypertension.Changes in the aging heart:• Chambers:• Increased left atrial cavity size•• Decreased left ventricular cavity size• Valves:• Fibrous thickening of valve leaflets••Aortic and mitral valve calcific deposits• Epicardial coronary arteries:• Diminished compliance• Calcific deposits• Atherosclerotic plaques• Myocardium:• Increased subepicardial fat• Brown atrophy• Lipofuscin deposition•Basophilic degeneration• Amyloid deposits• Aorta:• Dilated with a rightward shift• Elastic fragmentation and collagen accumulation•Atherosclerotic plaque

questions.question: What type of cells are heart failure cells?
questions.explanation: Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages. They are telltale signs of previousepisodes of pulmonary edema.In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within thealveolar spaces. These are then phagocytosed and digested by macrophages. The iron recoveredfrom haemoglobin is stored in the form of hemosiderin.The image given below shows heart failure cells within alveolar spaces.702Heart failure cellsHemosiderinladen macrophagesHeart failure cells

questions.question: What is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure?
questions.explanation: Hypertension is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure.Left-sided heart failure can be divided into systolic and diastolic failure. Diastolic failurepredominantly occurs in patients older than age 65 years. Here, the left ventricle is abnormallystiff and cannot relax during diastole.Causes of diastolic heart failure:•Hypertension: most common• Diabetes mellitus• Obesity• Bilateral renal artery stenosis703Systolic failure is due to insufficient ejection fraction, i.e., pump failure. It occurs when thecontractile function of the left ventricle is deranged.

questions.question: Which of the following does not cause isolated right-sided heart failure?
questions.explanation: Isolated right-sided heart failure is not caused by left-sided heart failure.Isolated right-sided heart failure is not common and usually occurs in patients with disordersaffecting the lungs. Therefore, it is often referred to as cor pulmonale. It is caused by disorders ofthe lung parenchyma and pulmonary vasculature. It is also caused by conditions causingpulmonary vasoconstriction like obstructive sleep apnea and altitude sickness.Pulmonary hypertension is the common feature of these disorders, which leads to hypertrophyand dilation of the right side of the heart.Right-sided heart failure is most commonly caused by left-sided heart failure. This is because anincrease in pressure in the pulmonary circulation from left-sided failure burdens the right side ofthe heart.

questions.question: A massive pulmonary embolism occurs in a patient with acute cor-pulmonale. Whatpathological changes do you expect in the heart of this patient?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, the patient has acute cor pulmonale. This causes right ventricular dilationwithout hypertrophy. On cross-section, the normal crescent shape of the right ventricle istransformed to a dilated ovoid.In chronic cor pulmonale, the right ventricular wall thickens. The hypertrophied right ventriclemay compress the left ventricular chamber. It can also cause regurgitation and fibrous thickeningof the tricuspid valve.

questions.question: The liver specimen obtained after the autopsy of a patient is given below. What could be thelikely cause of this finding?693
questions.explanation: In the image, the liver specimen shows a nutmeg liver appearance, which occurs in congestivehepatomegaly. This is secondary to passive congestion due to right heart failure.In right heart failure, there is congestion of hepatic and portal vessels, greatest around the centralveins. This leads to increased liver size and weight. The pericentral zones become congested andred-brown. The periportal regions are normal coloured and tan. This leads to a nutmeg liverappearance. With longstanding failure, the central areas can become fibrotic, eventuallyculminating in cardiac cirrhosis.Pathological changes are also seen in the spleen and the gastrointestinal tract. Portal venoushypertension also causes the enlargement of the spleen, with platelet sequestration. This is knownas congestive splenomegaly. This can also contribute to chronic congestion and oedema of thebowel.704

questions.question: Which hormone reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in women of reproductive age?
questions.explanation: Estrogen reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in women in the reproductive age group.Accelerated coronary artery disease is associated with the postmenopausal decline in estrogenproduction. However, postmenopausal hormonal replacement therapy (HRT) has not been shownto be beneficial.The most common cause of death in older women is ischemic heart disease.Through middle age, males have a relatively increased risk of myocardial infarction.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presented to the casualty with severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating tothe left arm. ECG showed ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. The person succumbedafter 3 hours. On autopsy, the patient's heart was immersed in triphenyl tetrazolium chloridesolution. What colour would be imparted to the heart?

options.B: Viable myocardium appears brick red and infarct appears pale
options.C: Viable myocardium appears red and infarct appears dark blue694
options.D: Viable myocardium appears unstained and the infarct appears dark red

questions.explanation: Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution imparts a brick red colour to the viable non-infarctedmyocardium. The infarct appears unstained and pale.Myocardial infarcts < 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, ifthe infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to identify the area of necrosis. This isdone by immersing the tissue slices in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution.The histochemical stain imparts a brick-red colour to intact, noninfarcted myocardium.Here, lactate dehydrogenase, LDH, activity is preserved. LDH leaks out through the damagedmembranes of dead cells, so an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.The image given below shows an ischemic brain after immersion in triphenyl tetrazolium chloridesolution. The pale unstained region is the infarcted zone.

questions.question: What is the approximate time of onset of microvascular injury in ischemic cardiac myocytes?
questions.explanation: Microvascular injury begins >1 hour after the onset of ischemia.705

questions.question: What is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction?
questions.explanation: Relaxation of myofibrils is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction.Myofibril relaxation, mitochondrial swelling and glycogen loss can be detected by electronmicroscopy within half an hour of myocardial infarction.

questions.question: You are conducting the autopsy of a patient who passed away following myocardial infarction.What would be the earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of thispatient?
questions.explanation: The earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient isthe waviness of myocardial fibres. This is seen within 2-4 hours at the border of the infarct.These changes are a result of the forceful contractions of viable fibres. The contractions causestretching and buckling of immediately adjacent, noncontractile dead fibres.Myocyte vacuolization or myocytolysis may also be seen in the infarct margins. It is due to theaccumulation of salt and water in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Such myocytes are viable but poorlycontractile.The image below shows microscopic features of myocardial infarction showing wavy myocardialfibres. There are wavy fibres that are elongated and narrow, as compared with normal fibres. Thewidened spaces between the dead fibres contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.a

questions.question: Following myocardial infarction, coagulative necrosis begins at?
questions.explanation: Early coagulative necrosis begins in myocardial infarction by 4–12 hours.However, it is prominent between 1 to 3 days after myocardial infarction.706

questions.question: The heart of a patient who had suffered a myocardial infarction is subjected to ahistopathological examination. The microscopic image is given below. What time followinginfarction would you observe this?
questions.explanation: The given image shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium. Early neutrophil infiltrationstarts by 12-24 hours following the infarction. It can be visualised by examination with a lightmicroscope.The necrotic myocardium elicits acute inflammation most prominent between 1 and 3.days. During this time, there is a brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils.The image given below shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium following MI.Neutrophilic infiltration in myocardiumMyocardiumNeutrophilicinfiltration

questions.question: A patient was admitted four days back following acute myocardial infarction. What type ofcells would you expect to see in the infarcted area in this patient?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, 4 days after MI, macrophages are seen in the infarcted area.They phagocytose dead myocytes at the border of the infarct earliest by 72 hours. Removal of thenecrotic myocytes is most noticeable by 3 to 7 days.The image below shows a macrophagic infiltrate in the infarcted area.707

questions.question: Match the following:
questions.explanation: The correct match is:• Well established granulation - 10 - 14 days•Complete scarring -> 2 months• Myocyte hypereosinophilia 12 - 24 hours• Grey white scar - 2-8 weeks•-• Loss of nuclei and striations - 1 - 3 days

questions.question: A 67-year-old woman is found dead in her home. On autopsy, hemopericardium secondary toventricular wall rupture is seen. How long before her death did she probably have amyocardial infarction?
questions.explanation: The given autopsy finding of hemopericardium secondary to ventricular wall rupture occurs mostfrequently 3-7 days after myocardial infarction (MI). During this time, the lysis of the necroticmyocardium is maximum. Thus most of the infarct has been converted to friable granulationtissue.The risk factors for free-wall rupture are:•Age > 60 years• Female gender• First MI•• Large, transmural and anterior MI• Absence of left ventricular hypertrophy• Preexisting hypertension708It is less frequent in patients with prior MI because associated fibrotic scarring inhibitsmyocardial tearing.Complications of MI:• Heart failure -• This is due to ventricular dysfunction caused by the infarct and ventricular remodeling••Usually occurs within a day•Cardiogenic shock -• This is usually seen in severe multivessel coronary artery disease due to extensive involvement ofmyocardium•Usually occurs within a day• Arrhythmias - most common complication, occurring usually 2 days after infarction• Most common arrhythmia within one hour of MI - ventricular fibrillation• Most common arrhythmia after one hour of MI - supraventricular tachycardia• Myocardial rupture - occurs when there is transmural necrosis of a ventricle. It includes thefollowing -.•• Left ventricular free wall rupture (most common) - leads to cardiac tamponadeInterventricular septal rupture - leads acute ventricular septal defect (VSD)• Papillary muscle rupture - leads to severe mitral regurgitation••••Mitral regurgitation (MR) - this can occur due to -Transient papillary muscle dysfunction - mid-systolic or late-systolic murmur• Rupture of papillary muscle - pansystolic murmur⚫ Dressler syndrome (post-MI syndrome) -• This is an immune-mediated reaction and presents as pericarditis, pleurisy, and fever• It can occur even 48 hrs after MI but usually occurs 1-6 weeks after MI and often subside after afew days•• Ventricular aneurysm• Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus

questions.question: What causes tigered myocardium?
questions.explanation: Tigered myocardium appearance occurs as a result of prolonged moderate hypoxia due to fattychange. It is the gross appearance of the heart with bands of yellow myocardium alternating withnormal myocardium.

questions.question: Which of the following causes the maximum damage in reperfusion injury?
questions.explanation: 709In reperfusion injury, the maximum damage is caused by free radicals.Reperfusion is the restoration of blood flow to the ischemic myocardium threatened by infarction.Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia.Once the flow is restored, there is bleeding.On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that areintensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closelypacked sarcomeres.Reperfusion injury may be mediated by:• Oxidative stress• Calcium overload• Inflammatory cells recruited after tissue reperfusion

questions.question: What creatine kinase isoenzymes do the heart muscle contain?
questions.explanation: Heart muscle contains MM and MB isoenzymes of creatine kinase.Creatine kinase (CK) has three isoenzymes:•• CK-1 (BB) - brain, nerve tissue, prostate (small amounts), intestine, lung, bladder, kidney, uterus,thyroid• CK-2 (MB) heart and skeletal muscle-•-CK-3 (MM) skeletal and heart muscleElevation of the CK-MB isoforms is seen in MI. CK-MB is lesssensitive and less specific, therefore, troponins are preferred for the diagnosis of MI. CK-MBbegins to rise within 3-12 hours of the onset of MI. It peaks at about 24 hours and returns tonormal within approximately 48-72 hours.

questions.question: A patient comes to the hospital after 3 hours of the onset of chest pain. ECG revealsST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Which of the following enzymes would beelevated in this patient?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI). Enzymes elevated after 4 to 8hours of MI are CK-MB (creatine kinase MB) and troponins.When cardiac troponin is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acuteMI. If it is the only assay available, it can be used, but it is far less sensitive and less specific.

questions.question: A 56-year-old man presented to the emergency department with progressive dyspnoea. Hiswife reports that he had chest pain 7 days back which had lasted for 2 days. You suspect thatthe patient's chest pain was due to myocardial infarction. If so, blood levels of which of thefollowing enzymes would be elevated now?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, on post-MI day 7, troponin and LDH will be raised. Troponins are highlyspecific for MI and remain elevated for 7 to 10 days.710Troponins are proteins that regulate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and skeletalmuscles. It is the single biomarker preferred for diagnosing MI, late diagnosis of MI, anddiagnosis of reinfarction. Troponin I is more important than troponin T.Cardiac troponin increases rapidly in patients with reinfarction. Sometimes, the cardiac troponinconcentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected reinfarction. Thenthe diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the cTn measurement.Myoglobin is the earliest enzyme to increase after MI. It is a protein that is found in the skeletaland cardiac muscles, which binds oxygen. It is a very sensitive indicator of muscle injury. But it isnot specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle.Myoglobin and SGOT levels come to baseline before day 1.

questions.question: Loss-of-function mutation in potassium channel gene KCNQ1 results in which of thefollowing?
questions.explanation: Loss of function mutation in K+ channel genes KCNQ1 and KCNH2 produces the long QTsyndrome. The gain-of-function mutation produces the short QT syndrome.Long QT syndrome manifests as arrhythmias associated with excessive prolongation of cardiacrepolarization. Stress-induced syncope or sudden cardiac death (SCD), are common presentations.Short QT syndrome presents with arrhythmias associated with abbreviated repolarizationintervals. They also present with palpitations, syncope, and SCD.711Brugada syndrome manifests as ECG abnormalities like ST-segment elevations and rightbundle-branch block. This occurs in the absence of structural heart disease. Here, patientsclassically present with syncope or SCD during rest or sleep or after large meals.Familial atrial fibrillation is caused by a gain of function mutation in genes coding potassiumchannels.

questions.question: What is the most common mechanism behind sudden cardiac death?
questions.explanation: The mechanism behind sudden cardiac death (SCD) is most often a lethal arrhythmia, e.g.,asystole or ventricular fibrillation.Coronary artery disease is the leading cause of SCD, responsible for 80% to 90% of cases. But, themechanism of SCD is most often a lethal arrhythmia. Infarction need not occur. Most of thepatients who have SCD but are successfully resuscitated do not show any enzymatic or ECGevidence of myocardial necrosis.Ischemic injury can directly affect the major components of the conduction system. But, mostcases of fatal arrhythmia are triggered by electrical irritability of the myocardium.

questions.question: Patients with which of the following conditions have an increased susceptibility to coronaryartery disease?
questions.explanation: Patients with hyperlipidemia have an increased susceptibility to coronary artery disease (CAD).Hyperlipidemia is considered the second most common risk factor for CAD worldwide afterhypertension. Hypercholesterolemia was implicated in 55% of cases with combinedhyperlipidemia in 41% cases.

options.A: ] composed of?a) apo B100 + apo A

questions.explanation: Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] contains the apolipoprotein B-100 portion of LDL linked to apolipoprotein A(apo A). It is an altered form of low-density lipoprotein (LDL).Increased Lp(a) levels are associated with coronary and cerebrovascular disease risk. It isindependent of total cholesterol or LDL levels.

questions.question: Histology of reperfused myocardium:
questions.explanation: Reperfused myocardium shows eosinophilic contraction bands on light microscopy. They occurin irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes, when blood supply is restored 12-24hours after MI.During ischemia, the intracellular levels of calcium are increased due to impaired calcium cyclingand sarcolemmal damage. This leads to augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils712after reperfusion.On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that areintensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closelypacked sarcomeres.Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia.This leads to bleeding after the flow is restored.713
